oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Soldiers setting up a Claymore anti-personnel mine
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two soldiers, both in helmets, setting up a Claymore anti-personnel mine. Both wear the signal brigade patch on their shoulders.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military uniforms; Hats; Helmets; Arms & armament
Vietnam War, 1961-1975; Vietnam; Qui Nhon (Vietnam)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ammons, Christopher D., 1948-
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Claymore anti-personnel mines contain a C-4 explosive charge and approximately 700 steel balls about the size of #4 birdshot. They can be detonated by remote control. When detonated they distribute the munitions in a 60-degree fan-shaped pattern because of the convex shape of the front of the charge. Thus a mine acts much like a large shotgun, peppering the area with metal fragments up to 100 meters in front of the mine.
